content: I never took a course on commutative algebra because in grad school I was mainly interested in mathematical physics, so I'm just finally now learning Nakayama's lemma - because I need it for something.

There are many alternative formulations, some perhaps easier to remember than others. MathOverflow someone gave this nice mnemonic for it which happens to match what I actually need:

IM=M  ⟹  im=m I M = M \implies i m = m IM=M⟹im=m

What does this mean? It means:

Nakayama's Lemma. Let III be an ideal in a commutative ring RRR and let MMM be a finitely generated RRR-module. If IM=MIM=MIM=M then there exists i∈Ii \in Ii∈I such that im=mim = mim=m for all m∈Mm \in Mm∈M.
This instantly implies something I wanted to know: if III is an ideal in a commutative ring RRR with I2=II^2 = II2=I, then I=pRI = p RI=pR for some p∈Rp \in Rp∈R with p2=pp^2 = pp2=p.

Starting from this simple formulation I'm finally getting more interested in the many alternative formulations and consequences, some of which sound more conceptual, like

If f:M→Mf: M \to Mf:M→M is a surjective endomorphism of a finitely generated RRR-module, then fff is an isomorphism.

or

Any basis of the fiber of a coherent sheaf at a point extends to a minimal generating set of local sections.

or

A finitely generated module over a local ring is projective only if it is free.

John Baez said:

This instantly implies something I wanted to know: if III is an ideal in a commutative ring RRR with I2=II^2 = II2=I, then I=pRI = p RI=pR for some p∈Rp \in Rp∈R with p2=pp^2 = pp2=p.

I don't understand how you get this instantly. And is it even true? I've seen it written on the internet with the additional hypothesis that III is finitely generated.

The ideal does have to be finitely generated to apply Nakayama's Lemma, indeed. But otherwise it's immediate, as:

  • an ideal inherits the structure of a module,
  • therefore there exists p∈Ip \in Ip∈I with pi=ipi = ipi=i for all i∈Ii \in Ii∈I,
  • in particular, p2=pp^2 = pp2=p,
  • pR⊆IpR \subseteq IpR⊆I since p∈Ip \in Ip∈I; I⊆pRI \subseteq pRI⊆pR since pI=IpI = IpI=I.

John Baez said:

Starting from this simple formulation I'm finally getting more interested in the many alternative formulations and consequences, some of which sound more conceptual, like

If f:M→Mf: M \to Mf:M→M is a surjective endomorphism of a finitely generated RRR-module, then fff is an isomorphism.

Yes, this is a good one. Nakayama's lemma seems to be like Yoneda's lemma, being one of these simple results that people in the know use all the time and is coincidentally named after a Japanese mathematician.

I'm not particularly in the know, but over a decade ago I wrote at the nLab, "Nakayama’s lemma is a simple but fundamental result of commutative algebra frequently used to lift information from the fiber of a sheaf over a point (as for example a coherent sheaf over a scheme) to give information on the stalk at that point".

I began writing the article after getting some glimmers of what it was really about (in the minds of people who really use the stuff) from this MathOverflow thread, I think especially the answer by Roy Smith. I especially like the application to the algebraic geometry form of the inverse function theorem.

James Deikun said:

The ideal does have to be finitely generated to apply Nakayama's Lemma, indeed.

Yes, I meant to say "finitely generated ideal".

Here's a nice counterexample when your ideal is not finitely generated. Let RRR be the ring of continuous complex-valued functions on [0,1][0,1][0,1] and let III be the ideal consisting of functions that vanish at 000. Then I2=II^2 = II2=I but III is not of the form pRp RpR for any idempotent p∈Rp \in Rp∈R (which would need to be a continuous function that only takes the values 000 and/or 111).

Todd Trimble said:

Nakayama's lemma seems to be like Yoneda's lemma, being one of these simple results that people in the know use all the time and is coincidentally named after a Japanese mathematician.

I was thinking about that. But what I'd really like to do is derive Nakayama's lemma from the Yoneda lemma! Then I could annoy people by saying "Nakayama's lemma? That's just a corollary of the Yoneda lemma."

Now, it may be hopeless to derive the Nakayama lemma from the Yoneda lemma. But the Nakayama lemma does follow from ideas connected to the Cayley-Hamilton theorem, and that theorem has a vaguely Yoneda-ish feel, at least in my fevered brain.

Remember, it says that if you take a square matrix AAA and define its characteristic polynomial ppp by

p(λ)=det(λI−A)p(\lambda) = \mathrm{det}(\lambda I - A)p(λ)=det(λI−A)

then you get

p(A)=0 p(A) = 0p(A)=0
There's some sort of weird self-reference here, like "AAA is the walking root of its own characteristic polynomial".
And that "walking" business feels vaguely Yoneda-esque (to my fevered brain).

Here's a fake one-line proof of the Cayley-Hamilton theorem:

p(A)=det(AI−A)=0p(A) = \mathrm{det}(A I - A) = 0p(A)=det(AI−A)=0

Puzzle for beginners: spot why this proof is fake.

Puzzle for experts: try to morph it into a real proof!

For what it's worth, the Cayley-Hamilton theorem is proved in the nLab here, as a relatively easy consequence of Cramer's rule. By the way, Cayley-Hamilton holds over any commutative ring.

I was thinking about that. But what I'd really like to do is derive Nakayama's lemma from the Yoneda lemma! Then I could annoy people by saying "Nakayama's lemma? That's just a corollary of the Yoneda lemma."

That's a fun motivation: finding a new way to annoy people using the Yoneda lemma. JK

I don't have a lot to say at the moment about a connection between the two, but it does remind me of stuff that Andre Scedrov said near the beginning of his AMS Memoir Forcing and Classifying Topoi. On page 11, he cites one of the standard approaches to proving the Cayley-Hamilton theorem as an example of universal thinking: "one always takes only the bare essentials needed to satisfy the hypothesis". So here, he says, "If ... PM(t)=det⁡(tI−M)P_M(t) = \det(tI - M)PM​(t)=det(tI−M), then showing PM(M)=0P_M(M) = 0PM​(M)=0 at once is too hard. Rather, think of tI−MtI - MtI−M as a matrix over k[t]k[t]k[t], EEE as a module over k[t]k[t]k[t], and show PM(t)E=0P_M(t)E = 0PM​(t)E=0 in this setting."

Where is he going with this? He's making an analogy with the process also described by Lawvere in his Variable Sets, Etendu, and Variable Structures in Topoi: just as one goes from a ring of constants kkk to k[t]k[t]k[t] by adjoining a variable, so one can move from "constant sets" to more "variable sets" (e.g., presheaf toposes), and then the forcing process (localizing with respect to forcing conditions) is analogous to taking a quotient modulo an ideal, tailor-made to fit the hypotheses one is after.

So there is the idea of using generic elements. In the Yoneda lemma, one considers an identity morphism as a "generic generalized element".

That's all I got at the moment... wish I had more.

James Deikun said:

Is there any good proof that doesn't make use of adjugates?

There's a kind of "dirty" proof where one sees that diagonal matrices DDD solve the characteristic polynomial equation (since p(D)p(D)p(D) for a polynomial ppp is a diagonal matrix whose diagonal entries are p(di)p(d_i)p(di​), where did_idi​ are the entries for DDD). Since the determinant is invariant under conjugation, we can then extend Cayley-Hamilton to the set of all diagonalizable matrices. Then, since diagonalizable matrices are dense in the set of all matrices, and since the set of matrices that satisfy CH is a closed set (even in the Zariski topology), the Cayley-Hamilton holds for all matrices.

One has to think a bit carefully though how well this holds up for all commutative rings. I'm not sure that density assertion does.

Ack, diagonalizable matrices are not dense of course. I guess I had in mind the classical case where the commutative ring is a field, and apply the idea that the statement of CH is insensitive to whether we stick with that field or pass to an extension field, and use this to pass to an algebraic closure and argue there. So, yeah, it's looking dirtier by the moment.

I consider free modules of finite rank over a given ring RRR.

Fix a rank 1 free module AAA (not necessarily with a given choice of isomorphism with RRR) and let (−)∗(-) ^\ast(−)∗ abbreviate the functor Hom(−,A)Hom(-, A)Hom(−,A).
A perfect pairing V⊗W→AV\otimes W\to AV⊗W→A is a map such that both ways of currying give isomorphisms, so V≅W∗V\cong W^\astV≅W∗ and W≅V∗W\cong V^\astW≅V∗.
For any perfect pairing σ:V≅W∗\sigma:V\cong W^\astσ:V≅W∗, and for TTT an endomorphism of VVV, construct a map

(σTσ−1)∗:W∗∗→W∗∗(\sigma T\sigma^{-1})^{\ast} :W^{\ast\ast} \to W^{\ast\ast}(σTσ−1)∗:W∗∗→W∗∗
and by virtue of the natural isomorphism W≅W∗∗W\cong W^{\ast\ast}W≅W∗∗ i can regard this as a map T♯:W→WT^\sharp:W\to WT♯:W→W.

This map is called the adjoint of TTT and is uniquely defined by ⟨Tv,w⟩=⟨v,T♯w⟩\left\langle Tv, w\right\rangle=\left\langle v, T^\sharp w\right\rangle ⟨Tv,w⟩=⟨v,T♯w⟩. Similarly if FFF is an endomorphism of WWW its adjoint is an endomorphism of VVV.

Now take VVV to be a free module of rank nnn, let W=Λn−1(V)W=\Lambda^{n-1}(V)W=Λn−1(V)
and take AAA to be Λn(V)\Lambda^{n}(V)Λn(V). The wedge product is a perfect pairing.

If TTT is any endomorphism of VVV then because the exterior algebra is a functor F=Λn−1(T)F=\Lambda^{n-1}(T)F=Λn−1(T) is an endomorphism of W=Λn−1(V)W=\Lambda^{n-1}(V)W=Λn−1(V). So it has an adjoint F♯F^\sharpF♯ which is an endomorphism of VVV. I call this endomorphism the adjugate of TTT.

Its defining property is that it satisfies
F♯(v)∧v2∧⋯∧vn=v∧T(v2)∧⋯∧T(vn)F^\sharp(v) \land v_2\land \dots\land v_n=v\land T(v_2)\land\dots\land T(v_n)F♯(v)∧v2​∧⋯∧vn​=v∧T(v2​)∧⋯∧T(vn​).

For any basis of VVV there are standard bases for WWW and AAA. Moreover as soon as a basis is fixed VVV is isomorphic to its dual space and so are WWW and AAA. I can describe the computation of the matrices arising from these but it will be a bit tedious, i will leave it as an exercise

it's helpful here to know that if TTT is an endomorphism of VVV then its determinant can be defined as the unique scalar rrr in RRR such that Λn(T)\Lambda^n(T)Λn(T) is equal to r⋅−r\cdot - r⋅− as endomorphisms of Λn(V)\Lambda^n(V)Λn(V).
that's why the adjugate is closely connected to the determinant.

From this perspective is there a way to make the adjugate still work for modules that are not free? Apparently the Cayley-Hamilton theorem itself still works in this situation, just as long as the ring is commutative.
(This is much nicer than picking a basis and manipulating a bunch of formulas though.)

There's a kind of "dirty" proof where one sees that diagonal matrices DDD solve the characteristic polynomial equation (since p(D)p(D)p(D) for a polynomial ppp is a diagonal matrix whose diagonal entries are p(di)p(d_i)p(di​), where did_idi​ are the entries for DDD). Since the determinant is invariant under conjugation, we can then extend Cayley-Hamilton to the set of all diagonalizable matrices. Then, since diagonalizable matrices are dense in the set of all matrices, and since the set of matrices that satisfy CH is a closed set (even in the Zariski topology), the Cayley-Hamilton holds for all matrices.

I kind of like dirty arguments where you prove something on a dense set and then use continuity to handle the rest. Maybe it's my background in analysis: these arguments come very naturally to me. For example, that's one of my favorite proofs of

exp⁡(tr(A))=det⁡(exp⁡(A)) \exp(\mathrm{tr}(A)) = \det(\exp(A)) exp(tr(A))=det(exp(A))

But you know this better than anyone, Todd - in our recent work I've been reaching for Zariski density arguments like a drunk reaches for his bottle. :upside_down:

Some interesting, and occasionally annoying, facts about commutative rings and their modules that I found out in the course of investigating all this:

  • A R-module M has a "coordinate ring" R[M]R[M]R[M] of polynomials freely generated as a commutative ring by the module homomorphisms from M to R. This may be somewhat degenerate if the module is not freely generated.
  • In the case where M is a finitely and freely generated module it has a module of polynomial self-maps M[M]=R[M]⊗RMM[M] = R[M] \otimes_R MM[M]=R[M]⊗R​M which inherits the structure of an R[M]R[M]R[M]-module via extension of scalars. In other cases it's not clear what M[M]M[M]M[M] should be but it's certainly not always an R[M]R[M]R[M]-module in any useful way.
  • In the case of an alternative (maybe even power-associative) R-algebra A which is finitely and freely generated as an R-module, it will at least "tend to" have a characteristic polynomial. You can extend the bilinear map μA:A⊗A→A\mu_A : A \otimes A \to AμA​:A⊗A→A to a map μA[A]:A[A]⊗A[A]→A[A]\mu_A[A] : A[A] \otimes A[A] \to A[A]μA​[A]:A[A]⊗A[A]→A[A] and then fix id (as a polynomial self-map of A) as the left argument, leaving a R[A]R[A]R[A]-linear endomap on A[A]A[A]A[A]; the subring Pow(A)\mathrm{Pow}(A)Pow(A) of End(A[A])\mathrm{End}(A[A])End(A[A]) generated by that endomap is commutative and hence by the universal property of polynomial rings there's a map from R[A][λ]R[A][\lambda]R[A][λ] to Pow(A)\mathrm{Pow}(A)Pow(A) sending λ\lambdaλ to the generator. For reasons yet unknown to me, the kernel of this map "tends to be" a principal ideal generated by a polynomial monic in λ\lambdaλ and homogenous in A,λA,\lambdaA,λ. Once you somehow prove this generator char.poly.A\mathrm{char. poly.}_Achar.poly.A​ exists, Cayley-Hamilton for it is immediate.
  • In the case of an alternative, but probably not power-associative, R-algebra A which is finitely and freely generated as an R-module, it will at least "tend to" have a determinant. A determinant is an element detA\mathrm{det}_AdetA​ of R[A]\mathrm{R[A]}R[A] which is homogeneous and evaluates to a homomorphism of (unital magmas?/loops?) from A to R.
  • You can go back and forth between characteristic polynomial and determinant when they are both defined. If the (identical) degree of char.poly.A\mathrm{char. poly.}_Achar.poly.A​ and detA\mathrm{det}_AdetA​ is r, then detA(u)=(−1)rchar.poly.A(u)(0)\mathrm{det}_A(u) = (-1)^r \mathrm{char. poly.}_A(u)(0)detA​(u)=(−1)rchar.poly.A​(u)(0) and char.poly.A(u)=detA(λIA−u)\mathrm{char. poly.}_A(u) = \mathrm{det}_A(\lambda I_A - u)char.poly.A​(u)=detA​(λIA​−u).

I'd really like to find more connections between, and justifications for, these facts. I've seen proofs for them in at least some special cases, but they seem more like "coincidences of calculation" than proper justifications.

Here is a more basis-free version of the nLab proof of Cayley-Hamilton. (Were people able to follow that proof? I seemed to need to use the transpose of AAA instead of AAA.)

Let RRR be a commutative ring, VVV a free RRR-module, and fff an endomorphism of VVV.

Let Vx=fV_{x=f}Vx=f​ denote the R[x]R[x]R[x]-module structure on VVV induced by the unique RRR-algebra map R[x]→Hom(V,V)R[x] \to \text{Hom}(V, V)R[x]→Hom(V,V) sending xxx to fff. Let F⊣UF ⊣ UF⊣U be the free-forgetful adjunction between R-ModR\text{-Mod}R-Mod and R[x]-ModR[x]\text{-Mod}R[x]-Mod. Let qqq denote the canonical map F(V)→Vx=fF(V) \to V_{x=f}F(V)→Vx=f​, which is the component of the adjunction counit at Vx=fV_{x=f}Vx=f​.

By the definition of Vx=fV_{x=f}Vx=f​, we have
U(x⋅id)=fU(x \cdot \text{id}) = fU(x⋅id)=f.

Naturality of the counit then yields
x⋅q=F(f);qx \cdot q = F(f);qx⋅q=F(f);q,
i.e.,
(x⋅id−F(f));q=0(x \cdot \text{id} - F(f));q = 0(x⋅id−F(f));q=0.

Hence,
det⁡(x⋅id−F(f))⋅q=adj(x⋅id−F(f));(x⋅id−F(f));q=0\det(x \cdot \text{id} - F(f)) \cdot q = \text{adj}(x \cdot \text{id} - F(f));(x \cdot \text{id} - F(f));q = 0det(x⋅id−F(f))⋅q=adj(x⋅id−F(f));(x⋅id−F(f));q=0.
